facts.text: Appeals by certificate from judgments and orders dated May 17, 1968 of the Allahabad High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 310 and 627 of 1968.
Appellants have been levied purchase tax as per notification issued by the Government under s. 3-D(1) of the U.P. Sales Tax Act, 1948 in respect of their dealings in Rab.
High Court repelled contentions challenging validity of s. 3-D(1) and concluded that the power conferred on the State Government under s. 3-D is valid and not hit by Art. 14.

legal_issues.text: Whether the power delegated to the executive under s. 3-D(1) of the U.P. Sales Tax Act, 1948 is excessive and bad in law.
Whether s. 3-D(1) infringes Art. 14 of the Constitution as it discriminates between registered dealers who purchase through licensed dealers and those who purchase through other dealers.

petitioner_arguments.text: Power delegated to the executive under s. 3-D(1) is excessive and bad in law.
Maximum rate fixed under s. 3-D(1) is unreasonably high.

Explanation to s. 3-D(1) discriminates by deeming registered dealer as first purchaser through licensed dealer, but agent as first purchaser otherwise; no justification for making unlicensed agent liable; no rational distinction between licensed and unlicensed dealers.

respondent_arguments.text: Power conferred on State Government under s. 3-D(1) is valid; conferment of power to fix rate within limits is permissible.

court_reasoning.text: Power to fix rate of tax is legislative but can be delegated if legislature lays down policy and guidelines; taxation involves economic/social aspects like availability, evasion, impact; needs flexibility for planning; executive reflects legislature; modern complexity necessitates delegation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislatures lack time, information, mobility for details.

court_reasoning.text: In State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley not unconstitutional to leave details like selection of goods, rates to executive; power here not excessive given legislative practice and rates in sales tax laws.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Whether delegation excessive depends on facts, nature, purposes.

court_reasoning.text: In Devi Dass Gopal Krishnan open to delegate fixing rate if upper limit prescribed; maximum rate not unreasonably high, no material to conclude otherwise.
Licensed dealers maintain accounts, furnish details; unlicensed do not, increasing evasion risk; power to classify under fiscal law larger; burden falls on principal; valid classification.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Power to levy tax includes preventing evasion; discrimination rule allows classification.

holdings.text: Power delegated under s. 3-D(1) to State Government to notify rates not exceeding specified limits (2 paisa/rupee for foodgrains, 5 paisa/rupee for others) is valid, not excessive delegation.
S. 3-D(1) and its Explanation not violative of Art. 14; classification between licensed and unlicensed dealers rational to prevent evasion.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley Co. (Madras) Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Not unconstitutional to delegate details like selection of goods, rates to executive in taxation laws.

precedents_cited.case_name: Devi Dass Gopal Krishnan and ors. v. The State of Punjab and ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Legislature may delegate power to fix rate of purchase/sales tax if reasonable upper limit prescribed.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Sales Tax Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Levy of purchase tax on first purchases at rates notified by State Government not exceeding limits; Explanation deems registered dealer first purchaser through licensed dealer.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: No violation as classification between licensed/unlicensed dealers rational for preventing evasion.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court upheld the Allahabad High Court's decision repelling challenges to s. 3-D(1) of the U.P. Sales Tax Act, 1948, finding no excessive delegation or violation of Art. 14, thereby validating the levy of purchase tax on appellants' dealings in Rab.

key_quotes.text: Whether a power delegated by the legislature to the executive has exceeded the permissible limits in a given case depends on its facts and circumstances. That question does not admit of any general rule.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The power of classification under a fiscal law is larger than in the case of other laws.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies distinction between licensed and unlicensed dealers under Art. 14.
